prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the post is in the wrong. The situation involves a husband setting up his office in the bedroom, causing disruptions for the wife who has to manage kids, chores, and her own work.

First, the husband chose the bedroom over the basement, which the wife suggested. His job is mostly conference calls, so he needs quiet. But the wife can't do basic things like shower or nap because of that. She's handling most of the housework and childcare, which is already a lot. 

The key points here are about mutual consideration. The husband's work requires a quiet environment, but the wife's needs are also valid. He's in a better position to move to the basement, which is available. By choosing the bedroom, he's creating a conflict that affects her daily life. The wife setting boundaries by saying she can't guarantee silence there is reasonable because she can't control the kids or other household activities. 

The husband's argument that she's the asshole for not being quiet ignores the fact that she's already making sacrifices. It's about shared responsibility. If he's willing to work from the basement, where he's guaranteed quiet, it would solve the problem without compromising her needs. The wife isn't wrong for prioritizing her own needs and the practicality of the situation. 

So, the answer is B. The author isn't in the wrong because the husband's choice to work in the bedroom creates these issues, and the wife is justified in setting boundaries to manage her own responsibilities.
